title: Roy Keane says racist abuse suffered by England stars in Bulgaria made him "sick to his stomach"
text:

Roy Keane declared himself “sick to his stomach” as England's Euro 2020 qualifier against Bulgaria was marred by racist abuse on Monday night.

Three Lions stars including Tyrone Mings and Raheem Sterling were racially abused during the match in Sofia, while some Bulgaria supporters also made Nazi salutes in the stands.

Kane stopped the game after 25 minutes when Raheem Sterling was brought down for a free kick.

Moments before, Aston Villa defender Mings, making his England debut, yelled "Hey, did you hear that?” to one of the assistant officials after monkey chants while in possession.

The game was stopped twice during the first half.

(Image: Andy Commins / Daily Mirror)

On the first occasion, the stadium announcer told the sparse 10,000 crowd, first in Bulgarian, then in English: "Attention please. This is an important announcement because of racist behaviour that is interfering with the game.

"The referee has indicated that the players will suspend the match. Racism will not be tolerated and the game will be abandoned if the racism continues.

"Help everyone enjoy the game and say no to racism.”

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

(Image: Sportimage)

That message was met by boos from sections of the home support - but applause from 3,800 travelling England fans.

As Sterling bagged his second and England's fifth on the night, away fans chanted: "Who put the ball in the racists' net? Raheem f*****g Sterling."

(Image: Getty Images)

Former Manchester United captain Keane, working for ITV in the stadium, declared at half-time, “that was horrible”.

The Irishman also pointed out how the scenes made him feel "sick to his stomach.”

Ian Wright, sitting alongside him, declared however how it was a "great day" for tackling racism - as it highlighted how players are now able to take a stand.

He said: "What you've got to understand now is you can feel physically sick. You've been on a football pitch, you know what it's like and you have to continue to play through that.

'But you don't now, and that's what's good. It's a great day, whatever anyone says.

(Image: 2019 Getty Images)

"It's a terrible day for Bulgarian people and how they've been represented, but it's a great day with respect of trying to tackle racism.

"You can see from that stand. What we're seeing is a set of fans that do not care and they need educating.

"As a black player, we've heard it for many years about walking off. It's something you do not want to do.

"You need the white players to do that for you, so you can go off together because you are a team together.

"When that can happen, and you see how powerful that is, you can do something."

Ex-England left-back Steven Warnock declared on BBC Radio 5 Live: “They [Bulgaria] should be banned straight away. They shouldn’t be able to make the Euros or World Cups for many years.

“You’ve got to hit them hard."
description: The Three Lions victory over Bulgaria in their Euro 2020 qualifier was marred by racist abuse and Nazi salutes
